entry.title: Re: Missing Email Template
entry.content:
Hello @PradeepV 

The Notifications tab in Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders appears only if there's at least one valid email template in the application tenant. The template MMPUR_CPR_DEFAULT_EMAIL_TMPL, referenced in KBA 3112088, is a Central Procurement template and isn't available in a standard CBC system unless the Central Procurement scope is activated.

For standard PO workflows in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, use the pre-provided PO templates instead.

  • MMPUR_PO_WFL_APPROVAL_EMAIL
  • MMPUR_PO_WFL_REJECTION_EMAIL

Steps to follow

  • In your Q/P tenant, open the Maintain Email Templates app.
  • Copy the predelivery PO workflow templates to your own namespace, like YY* 
  • Go to Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders → the Notifications tab will now be available → assign your template and recipients.

Below are some useful SAP Documentation references:

KBA 3304179 – Notification tab missing in purchasing workflows

KBA Note 3112088 – Create Email Notification Template for Purchasing Document Workflows

SAP Help – Maintain Email Templates

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: FBL5H: “Special G/L Transaction” Checkbox Disappears...
entry.content:
Hi @MuriloMachado 

Thank you for your question.

The behaviour you described is a known UI refresh issue. This occurs because the selection screen state does not retain the checkbox visibility properly after executing the report and navigating back without refreshing.

Here is a workaround that will help solve that. After returning to the selection screen, press Enter or interact with any field to refresh and display the checkbox again.

To permanently fix this, it may require a UI patch or note from SAP as it relates to session state management in FBL5H.  SAP has documented similar cases in Note 1396424.

So, it is a cosmetic/UI behaviour and not an issue impacting data or processing.

I hope this clarifies the issue and the temporary remedy. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics - Dock Appointment Scheduling: Maximum Capacity Blocker
entry.content:
Version

VersionDateChanges
1.021.08.2025Initial Version

 

General 

SAP Business Network for Logistics - Dock Appointment Scheduling now allows users to block an entire Loading Point’s capacity, including the overbooking limit, for specific periods across all shared docking locations.

Previously, users had to manually specify the blocked capacity, and overbooking limits could not be included. With the updated Manage Entities blocker feature, the system checks available capacity when creating blockers and alerts users if total capacity is exceeded to resolve potential capacity clashes.

Availability

Test TenantsThe feature was made available for Test Tenants of SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration with release 2508
Productive Tenantspending

For further information please check:

  • Release Schedule and Dates
  • What's New in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • What's New in the Test Tenants of SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration

Main features update

  • On Blocker creation, the available capacity of the Loading Point and respective time frame will be validated.
  • You can block the entire Loading Point regardless of the capacity defined across the validity periods. For example, different working hour capacities can now be blocked with one Blocker which spans different validity periods.
  • Blocking of the defined overbooking limit from the Loading Point is now possible.
  • Blockers can only be created if there is enough capacity. Users will be informed about capacity clashes and can react accordingly.

General Settings

Manage Entities – General Settings: Validity Period

Set your Loading Point validity periods in the Manage Entities app under Loading Point settings. You can specify capacity at these levels:

  • Loading Point Level
  • Validity Period Level
  • Working Hours Level

Timeslot duration and capacity for appointment booking are based on these settings.

For more information, see the SAP Help documentation (https://help.sap.com/docs/business-network-freight-collaboration/application-help/defining-loading-point-settings).

Before getting to the actual topic of this block, I just wanted to review the settings you might consider when setting up your Loading Points.

Sample Setting for “Working Hours Level” with different capacities during the day and Overbooking Limit:

  1. Enable “Time Slot Booking”.
    • Set “Capacity and Time Slot At” to your chosen Loading Point level.
  2. To use overbooking, enable “Overbooking”.
    • Set the “Overbooking Limit” for allowed extra appointments.
    • Choose who can overbook (“Overbooking for Carriers”); if disabled, only shippers may overbook.

  1. Configure the validity period for the Loading Point.
    • For example, selecting “Working Hours Level” allows you to assign varying capacities and time slot durations throughout the day.

Blocker Creation and Appointment Booking

Manage Dock Appointment – Appointment Booking

The system generates a calendar view using the Loading Point validity period. For example, available times are:

  • 08:00am – 12:00am
  • 01:00pm – 06:00pm

When booking an appointment, carriers (Self-Book Dock Appointments app) will see that slots are available, and shippers (Manage Dock Appointments app) receive information on the available slot capacity at the Loading Point:

  • 08:00am – 12:00am: Capacity = 9
  • 01:00pm – 06:00pm: Capacity = 6

Blocker Creation – General

The foundation for configuring a Loading Point to generate necessary time slots and capacities for appointment booking has now been established. This section addresses Blocker creation for Loading Points, either through Manage Entities or the Manage Dock Appointments application.

Previously, some scenarios were not supported, including:

  • Capacity checks during Blocker creation
  • Blocking an entire day with varying capacities across different validity periods
  • The inability to block exceeding the overbooking limit

Consider the following example illustrating how specific slots can be blocked:

Example: Shutting Down Loading Point(s) for an Entire Day

Current Functionality:

  • LP 1: Blocker 1: 08:00 AM – 12:00 PM, maximum capacity 9
  • LP 1: Blocker 2: 01:00 PM – 06:00 PM, maximum capacity 6
  • LP 2: Blocker 3: 08:00 AM – 06:00 PM, maximum capacity 12
  • LP 1 & LP 2: For these Loading Points, ensure that overbooking is deactivated in the loading point settings

Gap:

  • LP 1: It is not possible to block from 08:00am to 06:00pm for LP 1, as the system only permits blocking up to the maximum capacity of the validity period with the lowest capacity, which is 6; the remaining 3 units cannot be blocked.
  • LP 1 + LP 2: The overbooking limit set was not automatically blocked when creating a blocker and required separate deactivation for the Overbooking Limit at the loading point.

 

Blocker Creation – Manage Entities Loading Point

The new BN4L FC-DAS release will provide features to address existing gaps.

Maximum Capacity Including Overbooking

During blocker creation, users can now choose whether to block a specific capacity or the entire capacity of the Loading Point, including the Overbooking Limit. For instance, for LP 1, which has different capacities across working hours:

  • 08:00am – 12:00pm: Capacity = 9, Overbooking 1
  • 01:00pm – 06:00pm: Capacity = 6, Overbooking 1

It is now possible to create a single blocker spanning these hours and block the total capacity with overbooking. If the option to block the Maximum Capacity is selected, the Capacity input in the blocker is disabled, as all available capacity will be blocked.

In the Block Time table, the blocker entry in the Capacity column will indicate that Maximum Capacity and Overbooking were applied.

When maintaining an appointment, users can view the created blocker from 08:00am to 06:00pm on the calendar, and the Time Slots table will display those slots as unavailable throughout the defined period, regardless of the defined capacity.

Maximum Capacity without Overbooking

If you don't block the Overbooking Limit, it remains available for booking in both the Manage Dock Appointments app (for shippers) and the Self-Book Dock Appointments app (for carriers).

You can set the Overbooking Limit for shippers only or includes carriers as well.

For example, if the LP 1 Overbooking Limit is set to 1, one extra appointment can be made before the slot becomes unavailable.

This setting has to be activated for carriers additionally otherwise only shipper users can overbook a slot.

This also depends on the Loading Point settings, if the Overbooking for Carriers is enabled. If this is the case, for example, only the defined capacity in the Overbooking Limit can be booked.

In the Manage Dock Appointments and Self-Book Dock Appointments app, during the blocker time window, only “Available” is displayed, indicating that the slot is either booked or blocked and only overbooking capacity remains. Slots not impacted by the blocker continue to show both the number of available and booked slots.

Blocker Creation – Capacity Check

A capacity check is performed on Blocker when saving the Loading Point. If the total capacity (the sum of blocked capacity and booked appointments) exceeds the Loading Point's limit, a notification will be provided. Users will then have the option to adjust the blocker capacity or modify or cancel existing blockers and appointments.

The new blocker is overlapping with an existing blocker which already occupied the maximum available capacity of the Loading Point at this time window.

Follow the See More link to get the details of the overlapping blockers or appointments.

Note: The system checks for overlapping blockers in Manage Entities on the Load Point before reviewing appointments and blockers in Manage Dock Appointments or Self-Book Dock Appointments.

If no overlapping blocker with a capacity conflict is found in Manage Entities, the system checks Manage Dock Appointments, Self-Book Dock Appointments and lists any relevant appointments or blockers for user action. As shown below, two appointments are already booked, so the system will not allow the creation of a blocker that uses all available capacity. If operations cannot proceed during this time, existing appointments may need to be cancelled and rescheduled.

For example in Mange Dock Appointments the listed appointments can be found and relevant actions applied.

 

Manage Dock Appointments

Blocker Creation

In the Manage Dock Appointments app the blocker creation was adopted as well. The same options for Max. Capacity and Overbooking are available when creating a blocker.

Note: Blockers created in Manage Dock Appointments are not synched to Manage Entities and therefore capacity check will consider appointments and blockers available.

If you release a blocker which was created in Manage Entities, the deletion will not be reflected in Manage Entities.

 

 

 

Further Information

  • Release Schedule and Dates
  • What's New in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • What's New in the Test Tenants of SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • Shipper Apps and APIs - Dock Appointment Scheduling
  • Carrier Apps and APIs - Self-Book Dock Appointments
  • Shipper APIs (SOAP APIs) - Dock Appointment Scheduling
  • Business Accelerator Hub - SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration (SOAP API)

entry.title: Re: Sales order with error message V1427 could not be rep...
entry.content:
System asking for Development Key could be because it is classified as a local object ($TMP) or not assigned to a transportable package. What you can do is check the Package Assignment of Z_V1427 in SE80 or SE38. Ensure it’s not in $TMP. Transport the Program from development to production using a proper transport request. Assign the Program to a Package that’s part of your development namespace. If needed, request a developer key through your SAP Basis team; but ideally, this should be avoided in production.

As indicated in SAP Note 2118197, if you still face any issue, it is better to raise a ticket to SAP citing this note and ask for resolution.

entry.title: Re: System default Main budget clarification in SAP B1 [1...
entry.content:
Hi @Siva1220 ,

There are no restrictions on using the main budget scenario. The system creates it automatically as the baseline for Budget Control. It acts as the primary reference for budget checks and validations across modules (e.g., purchasing, financials). Additionally, SAP utilises this scenario to enforce budget limits when budget control is enabled.

I assume that, by locking and greying it out, SAP ensures that this scenario cannot be deleted or structurally modified, as many built-in reports and alerts in SAP B1 are designed to reference the Main Budget scenario. So, it ensures that there's always a default scenario available for comparison and analysis.

It does not affect reporting or future transactions, as long as the data is correctly structured.

I hope it helps.

BR,
Felipe

entry.title: Re: I can't create a cost center.
entry.content:
Hello @h-itou 

The error you see is expected in S/4 HANA Public cloud  , a Cost Center must always be linked to a Profit Center (mandatory integration of Cost Center Accounting with Profit Center Accounting). To resolve this, you need to ensure the Standard Hierarchy for Profit Centers is set up first.

Steps to follow:

Check Standard Hierarchy

    • App: Manage Global Hierarchies → Profit Center Standard Hierarchy.
    • Make sure the Standard Hierarchy is generated by the system during initial settup via CBC/SSCUI  Define Standard Hierarchy for Profit Center.

Create Profit Center

    • App: Manage Profit Centers.
    • Assign it to the Standard Hierarchy; the node in the hierarchy must exist before you can assign.
    • Save and activate the Profit Center.

Create Cost Center

  • App: Manage Cost Centers.
  • Enter the controlling area, validity period, and assign the Profit Center you just created.
  • Save and activate.

You cannot establish a Cost Centre until at least one Profit Centre exists and is assigned to the Standard Hierarchy.

SAP Helpful documentation

  • SAP Help – Manage Profit Centers
  • SAP Help – Manage Cost Centers
  • KBA-2697539 - Maintain Profit Center Configuration - Fiori

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: I can't create a cost center.
entry.content:
Profit Center Accounting is enabled by default in S/4HANA Cloud.

When creating a cost center, SAP expects a profit center assignment. But to assign a profit center, you need a Standard Hierarchy Node. And to assign a profit center to that node, the profit center must already exist. So yes, you're stuck in a loop—but here's how to resolve it.

To fix this, Create the Standard Hierarchy Node first by using the Manage Profit Center Groups app where, create a Profit Center Group (e.g., GLOBAL or YBPH). This becomes your Standard Hierarchy Node. If the app doesn’t show up, make sure your user role includes the Business Catalog - SAP_FIN_BC_PCGRP_MAINT_PC.

Then, use the Configure Your Solution app. Go to Finance → Master and Organizational Data → Profit Centers. Assign the newly created group as the Standard Hierarchy for your controlling area

Now use the Manage Profit Centers app and create a profit center and assign it to the node you just created. Ensure you activate the profit center after creation.

Finally, use the Manage Cost Centers app and now you can assign the profit center to the cost center. The error message will no longer appear

If you're still blocked, check SAP Note 3522633 which confirms that profit center assignment is mandatory when PCA is active in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

entry.title: Re: new output determination when changing sales document...
entry.content:
When you change the sales document type using the 'Alternative Sales Document Type' feature, SAP doesn’t automatically re-trigger output determination because:

  • the output determination is typically executed during initial creation.
  • BRF+ rules are based on the document status and context at creation, not on post-change events.

To force a re-evaluation of BRF+ output rules after changing the document type, follow the below steps

Go to "Output Parameter Determination" or "Manage Output Items". Select the affected document and choose "Reprocess Output". This manually triggers BRF+ to re-evaluate based on the new document type.

Ensure your BRF+ decision table includes Sales Document Type as a condition. Add logic to check for changes in document type and determine output accordingly.

Use SD_OUTPUT_DETERMINATION to hook into the output determination process. You can write custom logic to re-trigger output when the document type changes.

In some cases, you may need to delete existing output items and let the system recreate them based on the new document type. This can be done via API or manually in the output management UI.

entry.title: Join the Beta: Understanding tax calculations with Joule
entry.content:
Are you ready to influence the future of tax localization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

We’re inviting customers to participate in the beta testing program for a new Joule capability: Understanding Tax Calculations.

 

This feature, available for early access with release 2508.2, uses Generative AI to deliver real-time, contextual explanations of tax logic applied in posted sales orders. The current scope focuses on Sales Order-based tax calculations for India.

Billing clerks often spend valuable time interpreting tax rules to ensure compliance. This capability simplifies that process by providing clear, human-readable insights—directly within the application. The result: faster reviews, fewer errors, and greater confidence in tax accuracy.

As a beta participant, you’ll test the feature in your own SAP S/4HANA Cloud system and engage in regular feedback sessions with SAP’s development teams. Your input will directly shape how this AI-powered localization tool evolves.

Key Dates

  • Registration: July 1 – September 30, 2025
  • Program Start: October 20, 2025
  • Duration: 90 days

Seats are limited. To participate, you must be an SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customer or partner and sign a Test Evaluation Agreement.

Ready to get involved? Check out the Beta Testing program page and click the Register button at the top left to secure your spot.

entry.title: Meet SAP TechEd Community Speaker Marla Alschweiki
entry.content:
If you are traveling to Berlin, I hope you will make time to join Marla's community session.

CT1245 | Hugging Face Transformers in AI Foundation

Community Talk

Learn how to deploy Hugging Face Transformers in SAP AI Core, manage them via SAP AI Launchpad, and connect them to SAP apps like SAP Fiori or SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). This session shares architecture, tips, and real-world use cases for bringing custom NLP models into AI Foundation on SAP Business Technology Platform.

SAP TechEd Berlin - Session Catalog

Get to know Marla:
Marla is a Senior Data and AI Development Consultant with a strong curiosity and a passion for learning. Her current areas of expertise and interest are in SAP AI, machine learning, and data analytics.  She specializes in integrating AI capabilities into SAP systems, creating innovative and practical solutions for real-world enterprises needs.

Hobbies & Interests:
Outside of work, Marla likes to stay active and do some sport, learning languages (currently French), and spend time with her little puppy Carlo. 

Marla and Carlo

Why Attend Marla's Session:
At SAP TechEd, Marla will be presenting a session on leveraging Hugging Face Transformers in the SAP AI Foundation. She’ll explore how to bring cutting-edge NLP models into SAP BTP, deploy them seamlessly in SAP AI Core, manage them efficiently with AI Launchpad, and connect them to SAP apps like Fiori or CAP , Along the way, you might even pick up a few insider tips for confidently navigating Hugging Face like a pro.

I hope you make time for Marla's session.

entry.title: Can I install multiple versions of SAP Crystal Report runtime engine for .Net Framework
entry.content:
Hi,

We have some applications developed with Crystal Report for Visual Studio 2015 (CrystalDecisions references version 13.0.2000.0). On users' PC, we install SAP Crystal Report runtime engine for .Net Framework (64-bit) 13.0.18

Now we upgraded one of these application with new Crystal Report for Visual Studio 2022 (CrystalDecisions references version 13.0.4000.0). On users' PC, we need to install SAP Crystal Report runtime engine for .Net Framework (64-bit) 13.0.38 to allow users to run applications and view reports without any error.  But now for these PCs, when we try to run an application who has still the old Crystal references to 13.0.18, we get an error: Impossible to load file or assembly version 13.0.2000.0 PublicKeyToken=XXXXX.

Is it possible to install on a same PC both version of SAP Crystal Report runtime engine for .Net Framework (13.0.18 and 13.0.38)? Looks like it's not possible.

entry.title: SAP NOW AI Tour Brazil – August 19 & 20, São Paulo 2025
entry.content:
Over two days, more than 3,000 participants explored how AI and SAP solutions are shaping the future of business. With 300+ sessions, the event combined strategic keynotes, innovation showcases, and customer success stories at the Transamerica Expo Center in São Paulo.

 Key Takeaways:

  • Vision & Strategy: SAP leaders outlined how AI, data, and applications drive intelligent decision-making and business resilience.

  • Customer Success: Companies like Gerdau, São Salvador Alimentos, and the Grupo Aço Cearense shared tangible results with SAP S/4HANA and cloud solutions.

  • Innovation Challenge: The SAP Innovation Tournament highlighted disruptive use cases in generative AI and intelligent agents, with MRS Logística as the winner and Grupo Aço Cearense as one of the finalists.

  • Sustainability: SAP Brazil launched its 2024 Sustainability Report, reinforcing the importance of responsible innovation.

Community & Partners

It was a pleasure to connect with partners who are also active in the SAP Inside Track community — Solveplan, Makevalue, NUMEN, LAB2DEV, Stefanini, among others. Their passion and innovative solutions added to the success of the event.

Special mention to the Grupo Aço Cearense, not only for their innovation case but also for their strong engagement in SAP Inside Track Fortaleza and the SAP ecosystem in the Northeast of Brazil.

Another case study presented at the SAP Partner Makevalue booth showcased banking connectivity solutions in SAP, using APIs for major banks operating in Brazil. The solutions include collections, payments, and bank statements.

SAP NOW AI Brazil 2025 showed that AI is not just the future — it is already transforming SAP S/4HANA, SAP BTP, Business AI, and beyond.
The SAP community in Brazil remains vibrant, collaborative, and ready to co-create the future of business.

entry.title: Accounting Principles and SAP S/4HANA FI
entry.content:
It’s common to hear colleagues from other S4Hana modules express frustration with the complexity and impact of FI/CO on their processes. However, this perception often stems from a fundamental misunderstanding: the organizational structure of SAP S/4HANA Finance is not merely technical; it is the practical embodiment of the accounting principles that govern the financial governance of any organization.

Every object, from Company Code to Segment, is meticulously designed to ensure that financial records adhere to the pillars of accounting—promoting integrity, transparency, and, crucially, supporting strategic decision-making.

This article explores the intrinsic relationship between accounting principles and organizational objects in SAP S/4HANA FI, demystifying why their influence is so broad and vital to a company’s financial health. Get ready for an analysis that goes beyond technical configuration, diving into the accounting logic behind each system structure.

I’ve broken the concepts into levels to make them easier to understand.

 

Level 1: The Legal Entity and Going Concern in SAP S/4HANA

The starting point of any robust accounting system lies in properly defining the entity and in the premise of its uninterrupted operation. In SAP S/4HANA, these concepts are solidly embedded in its foundational organizational objects.

Entity Principle: The Company Code as the Legal Unit

The Entity Principle is one of the pillars of accounting, establishing that a company’s assets are distinct from those of its owners or shareholders. Accounting is therefore maintained for the business entity as an economically and legally separate unit.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Company Code is the most direct and crucial representation of this principle.

The Company Code is the smallest organizational unit for which a complete and self-contained set of accounts can be created, enabling the generation of external financial statements such as Balance Sheets and Income Statements, as required by law. Configuring a Company Code in SAP is, in fact, defining the legal and asset boundaries that the Entity Principle demands.

All financial transactions—whether purchases, sales, or payments—are recorded within a specific Company Code, ensuring segregation and clarity of each legal entity’s finances.

Going Concern Principle: The Long-Term Assumption in FI-AA

The Going Concern Principle assumes that the entity will continue operating indefinitely, with no intent of liquidation or significant downsizing. This is fundamental for classifying assets and liabilities (current vs. non-current) and, notably, for depreciating assets over their useful lives.

In SAP S/4HANA, the long-term existence of the Company Code, together with specific modules like Fixed Assets (FI-AA), reflects this principle directly.

FI-AA, configured per Company Code, manages asset depreciation across multiple years—a process that only makes sense under the assumption of continued operations. The system is inherently designed to handle the full lifecycle of assets and liabilities, which is a direct and systemic application of the Going Concern Principle.

 

Level 2: Measurement and Recording of Activities – The Basis of Accounting in S/4HANA

Once the entity is established, the next step is ensuring all financial activities are measured and recorded consistently and accurately. SAP S/4HANA provides robust tools aligned with essential accounting principles.

Monetary Unit Principle: Currency and Chart of Accounts

The Monetary Unit Principle requires all transactions and economic events to be expressed in a single currency. This enables aggregation, comparison, and consistent analysis of financial data.

In SAP S/4HANA, this principle is realized through the Company Code Currency and the Chart of Accounts.

Each Company Code is configured with a local currency (e.g., BRL, USD), in which all legal reports are generated. Regardless of the original transaction currency, amounts are converted and recorded in this common denominator. The Chart of Accounts, assigned to the Company Code, provides the structured hierarchy for recording economic events in an organized and standardized manner, allocating monetary values to categories such as Assets, Liabilities, Revenue, and Expenses.

Accrual and Matching Principles: The Universal Journal as the Core of Recording

The Accrual and Matching Principles are critical for accurate income determination.

  • Accrual Principle: Revenues and expenses must be recognized in the period in which they are generated, regardless of cash flow.

  • Matching Principle: Revenues must be matched with the expenses that contributed to generating them, preventing distortions in the Income Statement.

SAP S/4HANA fundamentally operates on an accrual basis. Fiscal Year Variants structure periods (usually monthly) and control postings, ensuring that an August sales invoice is recorded in August, even if payment occurs in September.

The Universal Journal (ACDOCA table) is the “single source of truth.” Every posting of revenue or expense is registered with both posting and document dates, ensuring proper period recognition. By unifying FI and CO data, the Universal Journal enables direct matching of revenues with their related costs—all in one place.

Native integration across SD (Sales & Distribution), MM (Materials Management), and FI automates matching. For instance, a goods issue in SD automatically triggers inventory reduction in MM and simultaneously records both Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) and revenue in FI. Likewise, FI-AA automatically posts depreciation monthly, while Cost Centers in CO record operating expenses that can be matched against generated results.

 

Level 3: Managerial Analysis and Reporting – Beyond Statutory Accounting

Beyond legal requirements, managers need granular insight into business performance. SAP S/4HANA applies accounting principles at an internal level to provide valuable managerial insights.

Segment Reporting (IFRS 8): The Segment Object

IFRS 8 (CPC 22 in Brazil) requires publicly traded companies to disclose information about their operating segments, enabling investors to analyze the business as management does.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Segment object is specifically designed for this. Derived at posting (often from Profit Centers), it enables real-time balance sheets and income statements per segment via the Universal Journal, providing unprecedented transparency into performance across business lines or geographies.

Internal Matching Principle: Profit Center and Cost Center

For managerial performance evaluation, revenues must be matched with the costs incurred to generate them.

  • Profit Center: Represents a unit accountable for its own P&L, capturing revenues and expenses. It applies the matching principle internally, enabling profitability analysis of products, branches, or divisions.

  • Cost Center: Represents where costs are incurred (e.g., HR, IT), without directly generating revenue. Costs are controlled here and can later be allocated to Profit Centers for full profitability analysis.

Together, Profit and Cost Centers close the cycle of internal matching.

 Prudence (Conservatism) Principle: Credit Control Area

The Prudence Principle dictates that, when in doubt, record the least favorable outcome—lower assets/revenues and higher liabilities/expenses. In practice, this means caution and recognition of probable losses.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Credit Control Area embodies this principle. By setting credit limits and monitoring exposures, it helps manage default risk. Functionality like provisions for doubtful accounts (bad debt allowances) within FI applies prudence directly, recognizing probable expenses before losses materialize.

 

Level 4: Information Quality and Systemic Governance in S/4HANA

Building an accounting structure is just step one. The next, equally critical, is ensuring that the information flowing through it is reliable, consistent, and accurate. SAP S/4HANA achieves this via its integrated architecture and intrinsic controls—systemic embodiments of governance and data quality principles.

Consistency Principle: Operational Chart of Accounts and Posting Models

The Consistency Principle requires that companies apply the same accounting practices across periods, allowing comparability over time. Changes are allowed only if preferable and properly disclosed.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Operational Chart of Accounts—once defined—becomes the backbone of all postings. Using a single chart across a group ensures uniform treatment of similar transactions across entities. Posting Models and Screen Variants enforce standardized postings for recurring transactions, reinforcing consistency and reducing manual errors.

Integrity, Completeness, and Synchronization of Data: Universal Journal and Native Integration

Data governance principles—Integrity, Completeness, Synchronization—are fundamental to information reliability.

  • Integrity ensures accuracy and trustworthiness.

  • Completeness ensures all required data is captured.

  • Synchronization ensures consistency across accounting, managerial, and logistics views.

The Universal Journal achieves this by merging FI, CO, FI-AA, CO-PA, and ML into a single line-item repository. This eliminates complex reconciliations.

Native integration ensures that when goods movement is posted in MM, the corresponding FI entry is simultaneously generated. No batch transfers that can fail; if one part fails, the transaction is reversed entirely, ensuring integrity.

The Universal Journal structure, containing all relevant fields (company, account, cost center, profit center, segment, etc.) in one table, ensures completeness. Its “single source of truth” architecture means all views—statutory and managerial—are instantly updated, eliminating reconciliations that plagued earlier SAP versions.

 

Conclusion: SAP S/4HANA as an Enabler of Accounting Governance

Understanding the deep connection between accounting principles and SAP S/4HANA FI architecture is crucial for every consultant. Far from being just a transactional system, S/4HANA is a platform that incorporates and automates accounting principles, ensuring not only legal compliance but also real-time financial insights for strategic decision-making.

By mastering this synergy, consultants can go beyond technical configuration and act as true business partners—optimizing processes, safeguarding data integrity, and maximizing the value SAP S/4HANA delivers to financial governance.

The evolution of ERP into S/4HANA represents a qualitative leap in how companies manage their finances—transforming accounting principles into operational and strategic reality.

entry.title: Marketing and Sales Digital Transformation Story: SAP Social Sabbatical Program - Bhayli & SAP
entry.content:
⭐Bhayli & SAP: One Team, One Dream ⭐ Jai Seva — Victory in Service ⭐

As I look back on my final week in Jaipur, it feels like the culmination of not just a project, but of a journey of growth, collaboration, and shared purpose. What began four weeks ago with introductions, first impressions, and a steep learning curve has now come full circle with a clear strategy, a strong partnership, and lasting memories.

The SAP Social Sabbatical program brings together SAP employees from around the world to support innovative non-profits and social enterprises, helping them tackle real business challenges. Every organisation we’re working with are aligned with the UN Sustainable Development Goals, which makes this experience extremely meaningful, as it is fully aligned with some of my most treasured core values. This opportunity hits close to home — using the skills I’ve built over the years to support communities and businesses doing good in the world has always been a personal pursuit.

This last week marked an important milestone in our work with Bhayli — a women-led initiative that empowers artisans and supports the circular economy by transforming waste into beautiful, meaningful products. Bhayli empowers rural women in Rajasthan by training them to transform waste materials — like plastic bottles and beverage cans — into beautifully handwoven and handcrafted products. You can find more about Bhayli’s mission and vision in their website here and Instagram account here. Together with my SAP teammates Lucrecia Maphupha and Nidia Miguel in collaboration with Bhayli, we finalized a new Marketing and Sales phased business approach designed to capacitate Bhayli scale sustainably, strengthen its partnerships, and expand its impact.

Bhayli & SAP: One Team, One Dream

 

Building the Strategy

The fourth and last program week was all about bringing together the insights we had gathered over the previous three weeks. We refined the customer journeys, aligned on marketing opportunities, and worked through pricing strategies that would make sense both for Bhayli and its creative partners. It was an intense but rewarding process of distilling complex discussions into a clear, actionable roadmap.

One of the highlights of our collaboration with Bhayli was running a design thinking workshop with their team. The session brought together artisans, partners, and our sabbatical group to reimagine how Bhayli could expand its reach while staying true to its mission. Using hands-on exercises, we mapped customer needs, brainstormed new opportunities. What stood out most was the energy in the room: every idea, no matter how simple, sparked discussion, and every prototype carried a sense of pride and possibility. It was a powerful experience that not only generated practical insights for Bhayli’s growth but also built a deeper sense of connection and shared purpose among everyone involved.

There were moments of debate, brainstorming, and back-and-forth alignment — but that’s exactly what made the process so powerful. Each one of us brought different perspectives, shaped by our backgrounds and experiences, and those perspectives enriched the final outcome. It wasn’t just a project handed over — it was a true collaboration, built on trust and respect.

Bhayli's Business Growth Framework

Bhayli Creative Partners

 

The Final Presentation

Our program concluded with the final presentation, where we officially handed over the project deliverables. Standing together as a team, sharing our recommendations, and watching the Bhayli leadership nod with excitement and recognition was a moment of pride. It reminded me why programs like the SAP Social Sabbatical exist: to connect corporate skills with social impact, and to create bridges between business frameworks and grassroots innovation.

The presentation was more than a transfer of work — it was a celebration of the journey we had shared with Bhayli’s team, from long discussions over chai, to creative workshops shaping recycled materials, to aligning on business strategy that will help them grow their mission.

Final Presentation

 

 

Reflections on the Journey

As I reflect on these four weeks, what stands out most are not just the deliverables, but the people and experiences behind them. I think of the women artisans at Bhayli, whose creativity and resilience give life to products that carry both beauty and purpose. I think of the chaotic but vibrant streets of Jaipur — the honking symphony of traffic, the monsoon rains, the shared laughter over spicy meals. I think of my teammates, who became more than colleagues — they became friends, united by the shared challenge of making an impact.

This sabbatical has taught me that impact is rarely linear. It is messy, unpredictable, and sometimes overwhelming — but it is also deeply rewarding. By stepping out of our comfort zones, immersing ourselves in a new culture, and working alongside local partners, we not only helped build solutions but also learned to see the world through different lenses.

Project closing event

 

 

Gratitude

I am incredibly grateful to everyone who made this experience possible. To my fellow team members Lucrecia and Nidia— thank you for your dedication, your creativity, and your energy. To the Bhayli team, thank you for opening your doors, sharing your story, and allowing us to walk alongside you in this chapter of your journey. And to Pyxera Global, especially Shilpa Ahluwalia , Matrena Martin and Amisha Choudhary, thank you for organizing, guiding, and supporting us every step of the way. A big thanks to my extended SAP Team who shared this Journey with me: Evelyn Fromm, Oscar Fonque, Gisela Picaro, Daniel Fritsch, May Seet, Vera Volgina, Sebastian Lutz, Jackson Rogers, Carrie Barth and Vani Barg. Lastly I want to thank my manager Sam Forel for supporting me in this endeavor.

 

SAP Social Sabbatical Extended Team

Closing Thoughts

When I joined the SAP Social Sabbatical in Jaipur, I knew it would be a unique opportunity, but I didn’t realize just how much it would change me. My role was to work with Bhayli on creating a phased sales and marketing plan to help boost their business. On paper, it sounded like a familiar challenge. In reality, it pushed me far beyond my comfort zone and gave me lessons I’ll carry with me for years.

 The biggest change I experienced was building resilience, adaptability, and cultural awareness. Working in a completely new environment, with different ways of thinking and operating, forced me to let go of assumptions and really listen. It taught me to adapt quickly, stay resilient when things didn’t go as planned, and appreciate perspectives very different from my own.

 On a personal level, this opened my horizons. I discovered so much about Indian culture, the dedication of the artisans, and the sense of community around the work. I found myself becoming more empathetic, not only toward others but also in how I see the world — valuing patience, creativity, and the human stories behind every business.

SAP Social Sabbatical Extended Team

 

Professionally, the experience sharpened skills I thought I already knew. Leading design thinking workshops in this context showed me the power of collaboration and creativity when diverse voices are brought together. Managing scope and expectations in an environment so different from my usual work strengthened my ability to navigate ambiguity and lead with clarity. As a former SAP CRM consultant focusing in marketing and sales business, it felt refreshing being able to use my knowledge in this context. In additional, my experience as Customer Success Manager in building relationships and retaining SAP Customers, also contributed to reflect on strategies and best practices that can be adopted by  Bhayli.
I also gained a deeper understanding of how businesses in India — and particularly artisan-driven businesses — operate, which gave me fresh insights into ecosystems far outside the corporate world. On top of that, having the chance to engage directly with C-level leaders from local organizations helped me grow my confidence in stakeholder management and strategic conversations.

 Looking back, Jaipur wasn’t just about contributing my expertise — it was about growing as a person and a professional. I came back with a stronger sense of resilience, an openness to new perspectives, and practical leadership skills that I apply every day as a Customer Success Manager. More than anything, it reminded me that real impact comes from empathy, collaboration, and the willingness to learn as much as you give.

As our sabbatical in Jaipur comes to an end, I carry with me not just professional learnings, but also personal reflections. This experience was a reminder that true change happens when people come together with openness, humility, and a shared vision for a better future.

Jaipur will always remain in my heart — not just as a place I visited, but as a community that welcomed me, challenged me, and inspired me. This is not the end, but the beginning of new ways of thinking about business, impact, and collaboration.

Extended SAP team and Jaipur Clients

 Shaping a Hand Embossed Hosting Tray

 

Hand Embossed Hosting Tray

entry.title: Implementing UI5 Search Field for Virtual Elements
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with Fiori Elements applications, the out-of-the-box search functionality usually triggers a backend OData filter request. This is great when all the fields you want to search on are persisted in the database.

But what happens when you need to search on a virtual/derived element (for example, a concatenated agreement text that doesn’t exist as a real DB field)?

In such cases, backend filtering is not possible. The request fails, or you end up with errors because the field isn’t filterable.

Recently, I faced exactly this challenge. The requirement was to allow the user to search Agreements inside a table, where the field PrfntlTrdAgrmtCnctntdText is only derived at runtime.

Here’s how I solved it by replacing the default search with a custom search field in a UI5 Controller Extension.

Why UI5 Search Field?

  • Default FE search: Sends a filter request to the backend.

  • Problem: My search field (PrfntlTrdAgrmtCnctntdText) was virtual → no DB persistence → backend rejects the filter.

  • Solution: Replace the default search with a sap.m.SearchField that applies filtering only on the client side (on already loaded table items).

Implementation Steps

1. Extend the Object Page Controller
In ObjectPageControllerExtension, I overrode the onAfterRendering method :

onAfterRendering: function () { 
  this.addSearchFieldToTable();
  this.changeColumnLayout();
}

2. Custom Search Field

addSearchFieldToTable: function () {
    const sId = "ObjectPageSearchFieldId"; // Replace with actual ID
    const oOldSearchField = sap.ui.getCore().byId(sId);

    if (oOldSearchField) {
        // Remove default backend filter binding
        oOldSearchField.getFilter().destroy();

        // Add new SearchField with custom handler
        const oNewSearchField = new sap.m.SearchField({
            placeholder: "{i18n>searchPlaceholder}",
            search: this.onSearch.bind(this)
        });

        oOldSearchField.setFilter(oNewSearchField);
    }
}

3. Client-Side Filtering

onSearch: function (oEvent) {
    const sQuery = (oEvent.getParameter("query") || "").trim().toLowerCase();
    const oTable = sap.ui.getCore().byId("ObjectPageTableId"); // Replace with actual ID

    if (!oTable) return;

    // Reset visibility
    oTable.getItems().forEach(oItem => oItem.setVisible(true));

    // Empty query → show all
    if (!sQuery || sQuery === "*") return;

    // Filter items by Agreements field
    oTable.getItems().forEach(oItem => {
        const oData = oItem.getBindingContext()?.getObject();
        const sAgreements = oData?.PrfntlTrdAgrmtCnctntdText || "";
        const aAgreements = sAgreements.split(",").map(a => a.trim().toLowerCase());

        const bMatch = aAgreements.some(a => a.includes(sQuery));
        oItem.setVisible(bMatch);
    });
}

Result 

  • Users can now search by Agreement text even though it’s a virtual field.

  • The filtering happens instantly on the UI without backend calls.

  • Backend remains clean since no invalid OData requests are sent.

Key Takeaways

  • Use client-side filtering when your search target is a virtual element.

  • This pattern can be reused in other scenarios where backend filtering isn’t possible (e.g., calculated fields, concatenated strings, or UI-only attributes).

Here are a few points of note:

The items need to be on a security domain separate from other items if you do not want the admin to be able to assign other courses.

The permission for the admin needs to include a security domain group that includes that specific domain. There is a possibility of having multiple security domain groups for a specific role, the group is used to break down the specific permissions of a role.

I think to fully help you would require further discussion on what you have currently, which parts are not working for you, and ultimately where you want to be. Please feel free to reach out directly if you would like to discuss further.

Heather

entry.title: Re: How to get available stock for production order in EW...
entry.content:
When you release a PP01 production order, ATP checks stock at the IM (Inventory Management) level, typically at the plant or storage location. However, EWM operates at a warehouse-level granularity, and it considers:

  • Bin-level availability
  • Reservations already made for other orders
  • Stock in transit or blocked
  • Control cycles and PSA (Production Supply Area) assignments

So even if ATP says “yes, stock is available,” EWM might say “nope, or already reserved.”

Follow the below steps to avoid this situation

  • Configure ATP to check MRP areas that reflect EWM-managed locations. This gives a more accurate picture of what's truly available.
  • In customizing (OPJJ), activate storage location inspection for your checking rule. This forces ATP to check availability at the storage location level, not just plant level.
  • Ensure your control cycles correctly link the PSA to the EWM-managed storage bin. If this link is broken or misconfigured, staging fails.
  • Use reservation strategies that prioritize staging for released orders. You can also implement logic to prevent over-reservation across multiple orders.

entry.title: Re: CR 2025 Filters selection not working
entry.content:
According to CR's supported platform for databases, Express versions are not supported:


Crystal Reports 2025 – Data Sources
Please consult the xlsx file CR2025 Data Access
Notes
• Crystal Reports is offered as a 64-bit native binary. It requires 64-bit data source middleware connectivity on all operating systems.
• Crystal Reports uses the 64-bit ODBC registry on all versions of Windows. To administer 64-bit ODBC DSNs on 64-bit versions of Windows, run the 64-bit ODBC
Administrator, located here: %windir%\System32\odbcad32.exe
 
Possibly one of these DB Clients may work though:
ODBC  Microsoft ODBC Driver 17 for SQL Server
OLEDB  Microsoft OLEDB Driver 18 for SQL Server
JDBC Microsoft JDBC Driver 8.2 for SQL Server
ODBC DataDirect ODBC (10)

It also depends on how the date field is defined, if they don't show up then CR can't determine the type being used.

entry.title: Re: Is B.sc degree enough for ABAP career
entry.content:
Yes a Professional Master degree is good but I recommend to concentrate on the below SAP technical side since you already have 2+ years

  • SAP Fiori/UI5: Front-end development for modern SAP apps
  • SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform): Cloud-based extensions and integrations
  • SAP CDS Views & RAP Model: For building scalable, cloud-ready applications
  • SAP Functional Modules: Like SD, MM, or FI if they want to pivot toward techno-functional roles

“ABAP is a strong foundation, but SAP is evolving fast; learning Fiori or RAP can make you future-proof.”

Also to stay tuned with the latest updates,

access this SCN forum as much as possible
SAP Learning Hub 
openSAP for free courses

These platforms offer continuous learning, networking, and access to experts.

entry.title: Re: Best Approach for Deleting a Company and All Its Data...
entry.content:
Hi @ValdevyPires 

Thank you for your question.

Regarding the request to delete a company code and all related data in SAP. It is important to note that deletion is generally not recommended or supported once the company code has transactional data across modules.

Here are some key points you should note:

Deleting a company code can cause data inconsistencies and legal/audit issues since financial and tax data must be retained for years. It may disrupt reporting, intercompany transactions, and external integrations.

Best practices include blocking the company code for further postings, closing and reconciling balances, and using SAP archiving solutions to manage historical data.

Data migration or system simplification can also be considered.

Physical deletion is possible only if no transactional data exists and is typically limited to pre-go-live scenarios.

Specialized third-party tools exist for complex data carve-outs but should be used with caution.

My recommendation is, instead of deletion, advise the customer to block and archive the company code, keeping the system compliant and consistent. For restructuring or simplification, involve SAP’s Data Management & Landscape Transformation team for a selective carve out or consolidation project.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

SAP Note 1820315 Data Archiving

entry.title: Re: Actual costing run leading ledger (4-4-5) and non lea...
entry.content:
Hi @kasireddych 

To run Actual Costing once for your main ledger with a 4-4-5 fiscal calendar and again for the India Stat ledger with an Apr-March calendar, the typical approach is for you to:

First, make sure you enable inventory valuation for both ledgers with their respective fiscal calendars.

Then you can run Actual Costing separately for each ledger considering its fiscal calendar period close. CKMLCP allows selection of ledger and period, so you can execute it once for your main ledger’s 4-4-5 month close and then again for the India Stat ledger’s calendar month close.

Please note that inn S/4HANA, material ledger supports multi-ledger parallel valuation allowing flexibility for different calendar periods. Many Indian companies using S/4HANA with Actual Costing run separate valuation and settlement for their India Stat books aligned with the statutory calendar, while maintaining the 4-4-5 calendar for corporate reporting.

Finally, do ensure careful configuration of fiscal year variants, ledger assignments, and inventory valuation settings in IMG and material ledger.

I hope this provides more insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Guide for migrating PI/PO B2B mappings to Integration Suite B2B TPM
entry.content:
There are a few steps you need to take before you can use the Figaf tool to migrate the B2B scenarios. You need to setup an environment that will enable you to process the EDI setup.

Migrating B2B from PI to Integration Suite will be a demanding task, that will take you some time to get familiar with. But with this guide, you will learn how to complete a migration to having an operational B2B scenario in the Integration Suite, which can be validated and regression tested.

The task here is performed using Figaf tool, but they can also be performed manually though expect that it will take much longer time. 

Notice this has been recorded on a preview of Figaf 2508, so if you are using older versions, there may be small differences.

Note, naming conventions: The naming conventions are essential for handling this in a larger perspective.   There is a purpose for using all settings as specified in the videos.

Before you can get started with the migration, you should install Figaf in your own environment and configure it. The best guide is this one.

You will be taken through the following procedural steps:

– Prepare Company, no video for this, since this is a basis one-time task

– Prepare Partner Profiles, using the Figaf fast-track

– Prepare MIGs, and ideally MAGs

– Prepare Integration Suite TPM Agreement Templates, using naming conventions

– Perform migration of PI/PO Operation mapping to Integration Suite TPM  

Create company

You should have created your self as a company and if required, the subsidiaries you will be using. I would recommend you check how Figaf creates the Partner profiles and add Identifiers and Systems in the same way.

Video Guide 1: Create B2B Partner Profiles

See how the Figaf B2B “PI to CPI migration” menu’s fast-track feature “Create Partner Profiles“, will help you to quickly prepare all the partner profiles with corresponding systems and identifiers, for your PI B2B migrations.

Video Guide 2: Creation of MIGs and MAGs 

As apart of the preparation for your PI B2B migration, you will need to define all MIGs, and ideally also MAGs, so that you can proceed to the preparation of agreement templates.

When migrating a B2B solution from PI, you will not be needing the MAG, but having them in place, even as empty mappings, will ensure that your Agreement Templates are better aligned using correct MIGs. Preparing MAGs (complete or not) is not required for the migration process, but advisable.  

Video Guide 3: B2B Agreement templates

How to prepare the mandatory B2B Agreement Templates for your full B2B scope of message formats (typeSystems).

Video Guide 4: B2B Migration

Now you are ready to perform the migration using Figaf’s “PI to CPI Migration” menu.

In this video you can see how to perform the migration, and how to re-use your PI test cases for the newly created agreement.

You will also see, how the B2B scenarios are easier to manage and monitor in the Figaf “B2B” menu.

entry.title: How to Specify SAP DMS Repository for Different Projects in SAP Build Process Automation?
entry.content:
Hi Community,

We’ve integrated SAP Document Management Service (DMS) with SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) by creating a destination in our BTP subaccount. After this setup, BPA forms started showing the option to upload documents, and the files are getting stored in DMS.

In our destination configuration, we specified a repository ID, and all uploaded documents are automatically saved in that specific repository. BPA is even organizing the documents by creating a dedicated folder for each form submission, which is great.

However, here’s the challenge:

We have multiple projects in BPA within the same subaccount, and we’d like to use different repositories for different projects. But currently, I don’t see any way in BPA to specify or override the repository per project or per form.

Is there a way to specify the DMS repository that a particular BPA project or process should use for file uploads?
If not directly in BPA, is there any workaround or recommendation?

Any insights or best practices would be appreciated!

entry.title: Creating Custom 'Document Definition' as part of 'Document and Reporting Compliance' process of SAP
entry.content:
Helpful links:

  • This link talks about the whole 'Statutory Reporting component (this link could be skipped and the subsequent document could be referred if one is already acquainted with the 'Statutory Reporting process of SAP'). Statutory Reporting
  • Our main focus as part of this post would be 'Defining Custom Statutory Reports by referring the SAP Shipped Report Definition (it's recommended to go through the document before proceeding ahead in order to understand the various sub-components involved like Parameter Definition, Query Definition , Document Definition , Schema, PDF Form Template etc. and how all these components are inter-linked). Define Statutory Reports  

Scope of this post:

  • 'Define Statutory Reports' section as part of Setting up the Statutory Reporting process would be covered which is done using a Fiori app with same name. Custom Development is required at this part of the process only which would be the main topic to be covered as part of this post.
  • SPRO Configurations required for Setting up the 'Run Compliance Reports' won't be covered as part of this post. Above mentioned helpful links and the already shipped Configurations should help in understanding and setting up the same.

Recommended having prior knowledge of:

  • XML Interface based AdobeForm building.
  • Little Knowledge of XML based .xsd Schema files.

Requirement: Requirement was to make some changes (adding some fields at Header and Item level) in the pdf format Document of the Italian Fixed Asset Register(IT_FXDAST_REG) Report Definition by copying the same to a Custom Version and thereby applying the needed changes as per the customer requirement.

Details of the steps involved:

Step 1 : Copy standard Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' to a Custom one say 'YY_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG'

This step will copy all the below mentioned 7 components of the Report Definition, out of these 3rd and 4th i.e. Query Definition and Document Definition respectively are the most important one for carrying out the Custom Changes.

i.) Properties

ii.) Parameter Definition

iii.) Query Definition

iv.) Document Definition

v.) Correspondence Definition

vi) Event Handler

vii.) Reported Items Log

Understanding the Parameter Definition, Query Definition and Document Definition components above briefly. Recommended to go through the document Creating a Report Definition

a.) Parameter Definition : This step defines the Input Parameters and its properties for a Report e.g. what and all should be the Input Parameters like Company Code , Asset Class etc. and the properties of these Input Parameters like Optional, Hidden, Read-Only etc. In-short its the same as defining the Selection Screen in ABAP ALV Report. Values for these Parameters are set during the Setting up of 'Run Compliance Reports' procedure.

Note: Activate this before proceeding to the next step else you won't be able to use these properly in the subsequent steps. In most cases you won't need to make any changes here. 

b.) Query Definition : As part of a Report  Document/Output there would be various Entities (like Header fields , Item columns , Footer fields etc.) which we would need to get filled or populated with respective data, using Query Definition option you can define the various Re-usable queries which can be used to map with the various entities of the final Report Document/Output.

Below is the overview of various Queries available as part of Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' , 

Note: Here, we have added one Custom Query and also we have Changed the Source of an Existing Query. 

Note: A Query can be defined with any of the below listed Data Source types:

c.) Document Definition : It's in this step where we would define or say structure the layout of the legal Report documents that should get generated during the Statutory Reporting process. While creating the document definition, you can also assign an existing schema, or create a new schema for the document. It is at this step where we map various entities/nodes of the final legal Report document with the Re-useable queries we defined in the previous step. Documents of Type XML, TXT, ALV, JSON, PDF and XBRL can be defined as part of this step. As part of this post we would be focusing mainly on the pdf Document Type.

Step 2 : Working with the Query Definition.

Here, we will define a new Query with Data Source Type as 'Database Table' and also we will customize an existing Query-Class based Query by attaching a Z Custom Class to it as Data Source.

a.) Creating a Custom Query with Data Source of type 'Database Tables'

Select Data Source Type as 'Database Tables/Views' from the drop down and provide the Table name in the Data Source Name field.

Scroll down and in the Filters section set the filters, Note: Here, Set the Filter as per the mapping cardinality(this is part of the next step that is Document Definition mapping). Suppose, if the cardinality is 1:1 that means only one record is expected to be fetched and returned by this query hence, the Filter parameter should also be passed accordingly, such that it returns only one record.

Here, for the field ANLKL (Asset Class) of Table ANKA we are setting the Filter criteria by passing value from the output of another Existing Query called FILE_SPLIT.

So this is just like below SELECT SINGLE query,

SELECT SINGLE * FROM anka WHERE anlkl EQ file_split-assetclass

b.) Customizing existing Query-Class based Query 'TOTAL_ASST_CLSS'  by attaching a Z Custom Class to it as Data Source.

Here, we copied the Standard Query Class CL_FIAAIT_REG_DATA to Z_TEST_CL_FIAAIT_REG_DATA and will make Changes in the Method 'GET_PDF_TOTAL_ASST_CLSS' which is indeed responsible for filling data into this Query that is 'TOTAL_ASST_CLSS'. What we did is added a Custom field in the Output Structure and filled some dummy value as shown below,

Set the Parameters same as it was before for this Query, note Whenever you change the Data Source Type of a Query its Paramters need to be set again.

Finally Select all the Queries and Activate them, Note: Until and unless all the Queries are activated you wont be able to use them in subsequent steps.

Step 3 : Working with the Document Definition.

Note: Refer the Standard pdf Report Document 'IT_FXDAST_REGISTER_PDF' shipped as part of Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' in parallel for understanding how various parameters need to be set while configuring this part.

Finally it's in this step where we would define or say structure the layout of the legal Report documents that should get generated during the Statutory Reporting process and map all the output elements with the Queries we created above in the previous step.

a.) Click on Add option and select 'Add with Schema/Query' from the drop-down and provide the Document ID ( e.g. here it is 'YYIT_FXDAST_REGISTER_PDF' ) and set Document Type as 'PDF'

Now, here we need to maintain the Schema, which is the most important part of Report Definition. Schema is the metadata or say skeleton of the Data Service which would be use in this case for providing the Interface/Context/Data to the AdobeForm which we would indeed used for Binding the output elements in AdobeForm Layout.

Note: Here we need to define a new Schema and hence Schema ID reason being we are going to add some Custom Fields which is not part of the Standard SAP Shipped Schema and Document.

If you check the Standard pdf Report Document 'IT_FXDAST_REGISTER_PDF' shipped as part of Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' the Schema ID attached there is 'IT_FXDAST_REG_7'. Download/Export this Schema and we will enhance this Schema to accommodate the Custom Fields we want to add to the pdf Output. A .xsd extension XML file would be downloade.

Now using any of the XML editing tool you are comfortable with like Notepad++ edit this .xsd Schema file to add the Custom fields:

We added Type declaration as well in the bottom,

So, as a summary we have added fields like below, i.e. added 2 Custom fields(CUSTOM_FIELD1_ERDAT and CUSTOM_FIELD2_AEDAT ) in the Top level flat Structure and this would be filled by the new Database Table based Query we created and also in the existing Nested Structure 'ASSET_CLASS_TOTALS' we have added a Custom field inside that and for deriving the value of that field we have changed the Class~Method based Query  'TOTAL_ASST_CLSS' as demonstrated in the previous step by creating a Custom Query Class. These things would get more clear once we step into the mapping part.

b.) Continuing ahead with Defining the PDF Document process, provide the below values,

Here, the main thing is Schema ID , generate a new Schema (like here I have generated with Schema ID YIT_FXDAST_REG_1) using the Schema .xsd file we created in the previous step. Secondly, attach a Form Template so here I have copied the SAP shipped AdobeForm 'IT_FXDAST_REG' to a Custom one 'YY_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG' and attached the same here. Do create a Custom Interface as well by copying the existing one, here it would be a XML Based Interface and the Form would be a Fragment based Form.

Note: Remaining other settings keep the same as it was with the SAP Standard one.

c.) Continuing ahead with mapping part,

Once, the Schema ID is generated and Uploaded, all the Entities/Fields which were in the .xsd Schema would start appearing in the Mapping tab. Now, here we need to map each of these fields with the Queries.

Note: We need to map the newly added 3 fields properly with the Query we added and changed, remaining other fields need to be mapped as it was in the Standard. We need to keep in mind that whenever a new Schema is uploaded all the Existing mapping gets wiped off and we need to map again.

Here for field CUSTOM_FIELD1_ERDAT we Selected Data Source as 'Query Column' and Corresponding Value part we will set using the F4 help, which will indeed show all the Queries we defined previously,

So, here we selected Corresponding Value as YY_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG_CUST_HDR Query's ERDAT field i.e. Y_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG_CUST_HDR-ERDAT . Do, the same for the remaining 2 fields as well.

Very Important:

1.) If any of your Query is not Active in the Query Definition Step then the F4 here won't work, hence make sure the the Query Definition part is fully Active.

2.) For the remaining Existing Fields refer the Existing Document definition and set all other parameters same like that for example Loop Query, Data Source, Corresponding Value if all these values are not set properly in the mapping then the Nested Structures and Flat structures elements won't work properly and Output won't be rendered correctly.

Step 4 : Making changes into the XML based AdobeForm Interface,

Open the XML based AdobeForm Interface say in this case YY_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG which was created by copying Standard SFP Interface IT_FXDAST_REG. Load the same .xsd Schema file using which we created the Schema in previous step.

Activate the Interface

Step 5 : Making changes in the AdobeForm layout.

Bind the newly added fields into the AdobeForm Output Elements, 

Activate.

With this we are done with the Document Definition part and now we can configure the Run Report and generate the Reports.

Output: 

Pointers helpful for an analyzing a execution:

1.) Run Program 'SRF_GENERATE' in SE38 for analysis a Report Execution,

Provide Report Definition and the Report Run UUID,

For getting the Report Run UUID either press F4 there or use Table SRF_REP_RUN , pass REPORT_RUN_ID from the 'Run Compliance Report' Fiori app,

2.) Some of the Statutory Reporting Framework related Codes which could be helpful while debugging and analysing:

a.) FM SRF_GENERATE_DOCUMENT , PERFORM generate_document > search for “DATA(lo_pdf_document) = NEW cl_srf_pdf_generator( )."

b.) CL_ SRF_GENERATOR~ PROCESS_ELEMENT_WO_ITERATION 

c.) CL_SRF_REPORT~RETRIEVE

Thanks,

Sijin
